Tejas Crash: IAF Pilot Killed In Dubai Crash Identified As Wing Commander Namansh Syal

All about the Tejas fighter jet



NEW DELHI: A Tejas fighter jet of the Indian Air Force crashed during an aerobatic display at the Dubai Air Show on Friday, killing its pilot, the IAF confirmed. The HAL-built light combat aircraft went down around 2.10pm (local time) after nosediving mid-maneuver on the final day of the event at Al Maktoum International Airport.The IAF said a court of inquiry has been ordered to determine the cause of the accident."An IAF Tejas aircraft met with an accident during an aerial display at the Dubai Air Show today. The pilot sustained fatal injuries in the accident. Indian Air Force deeply regrets the loss of life and stands firmly with the bereaved family in this time of grief," the statement read.Black smoke billowed over the airport as spectators, including women and children, looked on.The Dubai Airshow is being held this year from November 17–21 at the DWC Dubai Airshow Site.The government of Dubai confirmed the incident, stating that emergency teams were already on the scene."A Tejas fighter aircraft from India participating in today’s flying display at the Dubai Airshow has crashed, resulting in the tragic death of the pilot. Firefighting and emergency teams responded rapidly to the incident and are currently managing the situation on-site," the Government of Dubai Media Office said in a statement.The Tejas fighter jet is a 4.5-generation all-weather combat aircraft, developed by Hindustan Aeronautics Limited (HAL).HAL produces several variants of the aircraft, including single-seater fighters for both the Air Force and Navy, as well as twin-seater trainer versions for each service.The jet measures 13.2 metres in length, with a wingspan of 8.2 metres and a height of 4.4 metres. Powered by the GE F404-IN20 engine, it delivers 85 kN of thrust and can reach speeds of Mach 1.6. It has a service ceiling of 50,000 feet, can withstand +8g to –3.5g, and comes equipped with nine hardpoints for weapons and equipment.

The persona behind the charges

For weeks, New York’s dining scene has whispered about a woman who slipped through its most expensive dining rooms, feasted like a tastemaker and allegedly vanished before the bill arrived. Now, 34-year-old Pei Chung, whose curated online persona masked a string of dine-and-dash arrests, is facing an entirely different reckoning: eviction from her Williamsburg apartment owned by Eliot Spitzer. Her digital glamour and real-world debts have finally collided, and the fallout is no longer confined to restaurant tabs.A Brooklyn woman whose alleged dine-and-dash habits have made her a fixture in police blotters is now on the brink of losing her home.According to, 34-year-old Pei Chung is facing eviction on 2 December from her $3,350-a-month Williamsburg studio after falling nearly $40,000 behind on rent. The building is owned by former New York governor Eliot Spitzer.Court filings describe mounting complaints from neighbours and repeated police visits. In internal correspondence cited by the Post, building manager Bob Jenny told a tenant:Neighbours reported “repeated outbursts, visible signs of conflict, and disorder in the hallway,” while one resident wrote that loud arguments and vibrations “frequently” travelled through the walls.It is inside this well-appointed waterfront studio that Chung has filmed much of her social media content, posing in lingerie, showcasing designer labels and styling luxury purchases, even as rent went unpaid.Her eviction is now described by the building as “high on our priority list,” according to documents reviewed byBy the time her landlord moved to evict her, a clearer picture of Pei Chung’s life outside her Williamsburg apartment had already begun to emerge, one that New York restaurateurs were all too familiar with. According to, five separate arrests since late October tell a similar story: a woman who entered some of the city’s most admired dining rooms, ordered generously, projected confidence, and then allegedly refused to pay.At Francie, the Michelin-starred restaurant in Brooklyn, staff say the performance was polished. Chung arrived on 22 October, ordered a full spread, foie gras, carpaccio, bucatini, lamb and chocolate mousse, and only after finishing allegedly proposed that the meal be settled through her online presence. Co-owner John Winterman toldshe approached the bill almost as if an agreement already existed:When she returned less than three weeks later on 7 November, ordering another $83.83 worth of dishes, staff called police after she again allegedly refused payment. Winterman recalled the moment officers arrived:She was handcuffed at the bar as diners watched.Francie, however, was not an outlier. Over the same fortnight,reports she allegedly slipped out of Lavender Lake without paying a $97 tab, vanished for “45 minutes” at Peter Luger before staff located her hiding in the bathroom during bill time, and refused to pay a $135 bill at Motorino Pizza, leading to yet another arrest.What complicated matters further was the existence of her blog , curated, polished, and at times lyrical. Of the same Peter Luger steak she allegedly tried to evade paying for, she wrote:Across these episodes, the NYPD repeatedly charged her with theft of services and issued desk-appearance tickets, while restaurants compared notes about a woman whose social-media sophistication, they believed, was being used as leverage to avoid the very bills her online persona celebrated.According to, Chung is a 34-year-old Brooklyn resident of Taiwanese descent, with roughly 14,000 Instagram followers. Her carefully curated feed presents her as a luxury food and lifestyle influencer, posing in Cartier, Dior, Chanel and Burberry while documenting meals at New York’s most exclusive restaurants.Her LinkedIn lists former work as a user-experience consultant at JPMorgan Chase, with six years in tech and e-commerce.She earned a master’s in Information Experience Design from Pratt Institute in 2019, receiving a full merit scholarship. On social media, she describes herself as a former child prodigy, trained in violin, piano and ballet.But restaurateurs now say her online persona served as leverage, a means to pressure venues into comped meals or escape before paying.With the rent case now moving through housing court, the alleged dine-and-dash spree that once played out across New York’s restaurant scene has reached a new, defining consequence: Chung is at risk of losing the apartment that anchored her entire influencer lifestyle.
Article Summary: Pei Chung, 34, is facing eviction from her $3,350-a-month Williamsburg studio after falling nearly $40,000 behind on rent. The building is owned by former New York governor Eliot Spitzer. Chung is a 34-year-old Taiwanese resident of Brooklyn, with roughly 14,000 Instagram followers.
